name: (2E)-3-(2,6-dichlorophenyl)-2-(4-phenyl-1,3-thiazol-2-yl)prop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1218
Reason: 2E-3-(2,6-dichlorophenyl)-2-(4-phenyl-1,3-thiazol-2-yl)prop-2-enenitrile has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components: Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The compound has two fused aromatic rings, which typically increase the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity and pi-stacking interactions; this effect is estimated to add about +25 °C for each additional fused ring. The thiazole ring itself can contribute around +20 °C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity. The two phenyl groups can each add approximately +20 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The chlorine atoms can raise the melting point by approximately +5 °C due to increased molecular weight and the capacity for hydrogen bonding. The nitrile group can also contribute around +5 °C due to the presence of a polar functional group.
